user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of request_completed_callback:
```c
static void
request_completed_callback (void *cls,
                            struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                            void **req_cls,
                            enum MHD_RequestTerminationCode toe)
{
  struct Request *request = *req_cls;
  (void) cls;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) connection;  /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) toe;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  if (NULL == request)
    return;
  if (NULL != request->session)
    request->session->rc--;
  if (NULL != request->pp)
    MHD_destroy_post_processor (request->pp);
  free (request);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No calls to any of the <string.h> functions listed in MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn) appear in this function. The function only: assigns request = *req_cls, checks request for NULL, conditionally decrements an integer member (request->session->rc--), calls MHD_destroy_post_processor(), and calls free(). None of these are string.h functions or directly perform buffer/string operations that could access beyond object bounds as defined by Rule 21.17.

Notes on other operations (not relevant to Rule 21.17):
- The dereference of req_cls (struct Request *request = *req_cls;) lacks an explicit NULL check on req_cls itself; this is a potential general pointer-safety issue but not related to use of string.h functions and therefore outside the scope of Rule 21.17.
- Calls to MHD_destroy_post_processor and free are not string.h functions and do not trigger Rule 21.17 checks here (their internal implementations are not shown; if they use string.h functions, those implementations should be reviewed separately).

Because no string.h functions are used in the shown code, there are no code fragments in this function that require investigation specifically for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
